title: anyone taking advantage of the down market

content: People could make a killing in this market. GM is down 85%, and we all know the gubbmint isn't going to let GM go under. Hell, good, solid performers like GE that are still posting a profit and paying solid dividends even these last 2 quarters are down over 50%. Of course, not that many people have a buttload of money tied up in CDs, t-bills, gold or other stuff that didn't get killed...anyone who socks everything away into CDs isn't going to put money in the stock market no matter how cheap the stocks get.

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: quote: Originally posted by jwr6: People could make a killing in this market. GM is down 85%, and we all know the gubbmint isn't going to let GM go under. Hell, good, solid performers like GE that are still posting a profit and paying solid dividends even these last 2 quarters are down over 50%. Of course, not that many people have a buttload of money tied up in CDs, t-bills, gold or other stuff that didn't get killed...anyone who socks everything away into CDs isn't going to put money in the stock market no matter how cheap the stocks get. IF SOMEONE CAN PUT FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS TOGETHER AND GO TO SCOTT TRADE AND JUST GET SOM C OR AIG, HECK AIG UNDER A BUCK BOTH SHARES TWO YEARS AGO WERE AT CLOSE TO 70.00 FIVE HUNDRED SHARES OF AIG WOULD BE 300.00 WAIT A YEAR AND WHEN IT RISES AND IT WILL CLEAR OUT AND POCKET A COUPLE OF GRAND Less than 2 weeks ago AIG was at .35. It would have been great to get in then, and cash out now but hindsight is 20/20. Buying AIG, C, BAC, or GM are all possible moneymakers, but it is pure gambling. If you are going to put your money into something I would shop around. I won't buy GM, but I do own Ford. I will speculate sometimes, but why buy a losing company like GM when F is available for less and they are much more stable.

I will speculate sometimes, but why buy a losing company like GM when F is available for less and they are much more stable.

title: anyone taking advantage of the down market

content: I am taking advantage of the down market, but I sure as heck am not buying any financials except for JPM (which I sold on Friday). There are so many others that are hitting 30%-40% from day to day there is no reason to go with something that is only hitting a few points here and there. And, I am not confident that they are a good long term just yet because I am still waiting for their impending bankruptcy after the bailout loans end. Once they file, then I may consider buying depending upon what the conditions are in the bankruptcy. This message has been edited. Last edited by: 10Tenths, Mon 16 March 2009 02:10 PM
reply: I am taking advantage of the down market, but I sure as heck am not buying any financials except for JPM (which I sold on Friday). There are so many others that are hitting 30%-40% from day to day there is no reason to go with something that is only hitting a few points here and there. content: quote: Originally posted by jwr6: People could make a killing in this market. GM is down 85%, and we all know the gubbmint isn't going to let GM go under. Hell, good, solid performers like GE that are still posting a profit and paying solid dividends even these last 2 quarters are down over 50%. Of course, not that many people have a buttload of money tied up in CDs, t-bills, gold or other stuff that didn't get killed...anyone who socks everything away into CDs isn't going to put money in the stock market no matter how cheap the stocks get. True... it is doubtful that GM will be allowed to fall... however it is very possible that the US assistance may not arrive until AFTER GM files for bankruptcy protections. At which point your investment is worthless

True... it is doubtful that GM will be allowed to fall... however it is very possible that the US assistance may not arrive until AFTER GM files for bankruptcy protections. At which point your investment is worthless The government isn't going to let Fannie Mae or AIG fail either and they are both stuck in penny stock hell. They are great for a quick buck on a 10 or 15 cent jump, but horrible for a long term investment. GM probably won't go away, but Chapter 11 is very possible before a massive reorganization.

GM probably won't go away, but Chapter 11 is very possible before a massive reorganization. quote: DETROIT (AP) -- General Motors Chief Executive Rick Wagoner says the automaker would end up being liquidated if it enters Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Wagoner says restructuring out of court would accomplish 99 percent of what could be achieved in bankruptcy. But he says it wouldn't have the risk of scaring away customers or the huge expense of Chapter 11. Wagoner made the statements Tuesday at a breakfast in Washington, D.C., sponsored by the Christian Science Monitor. General Motors Corp. has received $13.4 billion in federal loans and is seeking another $16.6 billion. The company faces a March 31 deadline to finish its viability plan and show the government it's worthy of the money. -http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/090317/gm_wagoner.html
